journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Effect of heat treatment on the magnetic behaviour of powder steel 50Ni2Mo under uni-axial tension

article-meta.aff: 1Institute of Engineering Science, RAS (Ural Branch), Ekaterinburg, Russia

author-notes.corresp: *Institute of Engineering Science, RAS (Ural Branch), 34 Komsomolskaya Street, Ekaterinburg 620049, Russia. email: subachev@imach.uran.ru

abstract.p: In this study, investigation results on the effect of heat treatment conditions on the mechanical properties, internal stresses, magnetic characteristics, and electrical resistivity of powder steel 50Ni2Mo are presented. Coercive force and maximum magnetization are shown to be applicable as magnetic test parameters to reveal underheating for quenching. Heating for quenching above the critical point Ac3 up to 910°С has an insignificant effect on the mechanical characteristics of the steel tested. It has been demonstrated that the use of the coercive force measured on minor magnetic hysteresis loops is preferable when estimating the level of applied tensile stresses in heat-treated powder steel 50Ni2Mo.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: The structural states of products made of structural steels by powder metallurgy are known to have residual porosity, heterogeneity in the content of carbon, and other alloying elements and high contents of impurities, non-metallic inclusions at the inter-particle boundaries, etc. This is, first of all, because powder steels are produced without steel melting.

In order to attain better strength properties, products made of powder carbon steels are often subjected to heat treatment, namely, quenching with subsequent tempering [1]. Since carbon and other alloying elements are heterogeneously distributed in sintered steels, as distinct from conventional cast ones, the physico-mechanical characteristics of the former after heat treatment can be significantly diverse. When striving for high product quality, one faces an urgent problem of non-destructive testing of the structural state and strength characteristics of heat-treated powder products.

Magnetic techniques, being fairly sensitive to the structural transformations occurring in steels under quenching and tempering and easy to apply [2], are widely used to test the quality of heat-treated products made of cast steels. Magnetic non-destructive techniques are promising for estimating the level ofacting stresses in steel products and structural members under operation [3]. However, there seems to be lack of works on magnetic structuroscopy of heat-treated powder steel products [4–6]. The works available deal only with certain aspects of the problem. Particularly, calibration graphs were constructed to determine the ‘goodness range’ of heat-treated powder products by magnetic characteristics. However, correlation between the magnetic and strength properties of powder steels was hardly discussed in the works.

This article offers the investigation results on the behaviour of the physical and mechanical properties of powder structural steel 50Ni2Mo as dependent on the temperature of quenching and tempering. The effect of uni-axial tension on the magnetic behaviour has also been studied in order to find how the level of acting stresses in products made of this steel could be estimated by magnetic techniques during operation.

sec.title: 2 MATERIALS AND EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURE
sec.p: Specimens made of powder steel 50Ni2Mo with a porosity of P ≈ 5 per cent were used as a test material. The specimens were made by double pressing and sintering of mixed powders of iron, graphite (∼0.54 mass%), nickel (∼2.0 mass%), and molybdenum (∼0.3 mass%), with a supplement of zinc stearate, at 1200°С in a continuous furnace, in a dissociated ammonia atmosphere, within 2 h. Carbon content in the specimens was estimated by the chemical analysis of witness specimens and, indirectly, by a magnetic two-parameter method, by measuring the coercive force of the specimens in view of their porosity [6, 7].

The gauge part of the specimens had a rectangular cross-section of 3 × 5 mm2 and a length of 40 mm. Specimen density (porosity) was measured by hydrostatic weighing in glycerine, with an error not exceeding 5 per cent.

The specimens were oil-quenched from 700°С, 730°С, 760°С, 790°С, 820°С, 850°С, 880°С, and 910°С. Soaking at the quenching temperature was done for 20 min. Specimens quenched from 820°С were tempered at 150–650°С (Table 1) within an hour with furnace cooling. Each heat treatment regime was applied to two specimens. Table 1
Heat treatment conditions for powder steel 50Ni2Mo
Temperatures for quenching (°С)
700 730 760 790 820 850 880 910
Tempering temperatures (°С)
150 200 250 300 400 450 490 530 570 610 650

X-ray diffraction analysis was made on a diffractometer in Kα-radiation of a chromium anode. Internal microstresses in the metal were determined by the ‘sin2 ψ’ technique, the crystal lattice microdistortions Δd/d being assessed by the Wilson moment method [8].

Vickers microhardness was determined by an automated microhardness meter under a load of 0.49 N by taking the average of ten measurements. To prevent the indenter from getting into a pore, the measurements were made with a preliminary selection of a poreless area on a metallographic specimen, with a magnification of 1500×.

Magnetic measurements were made in a closed magnetic permeameter-type circuit. A magnetic field was applied along the specimen axis, and the maximum strength of the internal field in the specimens reached 60 kA/m. The values of coercive force Hc, residual induction Br, maximum magnetic permeability µmax, and maximum magnetization Mmax (magnetization in a maximum applied field) were obtained from the initial magnetization curves and hysteresis loops. The measurement error for the field and induction did not exceed 3 per cent in the maximum applied field and in medium fields, and 8 per cent in low fields (Rayleigh region).

The electrical resistivity ρ of the specimens was determined by a four-wire scheme with a micro-ohmmeter, by measuring active electrical resistance on a length of 22 mm in the middle of the specimen gauge part. The measurement error did not exceed 8 per cent.
The yield stress σ0.2 and ultimate strength σu were determined in uni-axial tension according to State Standard Specification 1497-84.

sec.title: 3 RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
sec.p:
After sintering, the specimen structure was a ferrite–pearlite mixture (Fig. 1(a)) with a microhardness of 1.80 GPa. The crystal lattice microdistortions were 0.09 per cent, the macrostresses being −100 MPa. The specimens had the following magnetic properties: coercive force 820 A/m, maximum magnetic permeability 460, residual magnetic induction 0.86 T, and maximum magnetization (μ0Mmax) 1.8 T. Fig. 1
The structure of powder steel 50Ni2Mo: after sintering (а); after quenching from 700°С (b)and 760°С (c). Magnification 500×

After heating to 700°С and subsequent oil cooling, the X-ray phase analysis revealed no retained austenite in the specimens (they preserve their ferrite–pearlite structure; Fig. 1(b)). The microhardness of the specimens remains the same. The value of maximum magnetization remains practically unchanged (Fig. 2(d)). All this suggests that there is no steel austenization under heating. However, compressive macrostresses grow to −170 MPa. Under heat treatment of the kind, it is heat stresses caused by the non-uniform surface and bulk cooling that seem to have a decisive effect on the internal stresses [9]. In fact, this heat treatment is high-temperature annealing with accelerated cooling, as evidenced by lower crystal lattice microdistortions (to 0.06 per cent). This is confirmed by the measurements of the magnetic characteristics, namely, the coercive force is 24 percent lower than the initial value, i.e. after sintering, the maximum magnetic permeability and residual induction being, respectively, 54 and 31 per cent higher. Note that magnetic characteristics represent the situation more adequately, as they are representative of the state throughout the specimen section, as distinct from X-ray data and microhardness, which are representative only of the state of the surface layer. Fig. 2
The magnetic characteristics of powder steel 50Ni2Mo affected by quenching temperature. The dashed line marks the temperature Ac3; µ0 = 4π × 10−7 H/m is the magnetic constant

In the structure of the specimens quenched from 730°С, the X-ray diffraction analysis revealed some quantity of retained austenite (5 per cent or less). The presence of austenite is confirmed by about 10 per cent lower Mmax (Fig. 2(d)). The hardness of the steel quenched from 730°С is twice as high as that in the initial state and reaches 3.75 GPa, the internal stresses remaining at the same level. Hc grows and µmax decreases. The temperature of 730°С is seen to correspond to the two-phase region α + γ.

After quenching from 760°С, the hardness is 8.25–8.50 GPa, the crystal lattice microdistortions are about 0.24 per cent, and this is four times as high as after sintering. The tetragonal split of the diffraction peaks on the X-ray picture is testimony to the appearance of martensite. The value of the coercive force is four times as high as in the initial state (Fig. 2(a)).

In quenching from above 760°С, the physico-mechanical properties change only slightly, and this testifies that carbon concentration in a solid solution and austenite content in steel remain practically unchanged. It has been found from the X-ray diffraction analysis that the content of retained austenite in specimens quenched from above 760°С does not exceed 15 per cent. The presence of austenite in the structure is confirmed by microstructural studies (Fig.1(c)). The austenite content is slightly higher according to the X-ray diffraction analysis than according to magnetic measurements, which, as stated above, show that Mmax goes down by not more than 10 per cent. This discordance may be due to a difference between the surface and bulk states.

Only a slight change in the physico-mechanical characteristics of the specimens at quenching temperatures from 760°С and higher (Fig. 2) suggests that powder steel 50Ni2Mo is completely quenched by cooling from temperatures not lower than 760°С. The most preferable parameter for non-destructive testing of underheating for quenching of powder steel 50Ni2Mo is coercive force. It follows from the results obtained that the elevation of the temperature for quenching to 910°С causes no significant increase in the austenite grain size and, hence, no decrease in the strength characteristics of the steel. Therefore, itis more important to test underheating for quenching.

To study the effect of tempering temperatures on the physico-mechanical properties of the steel, to avoid underheating, the quenching temperature of 820°С was selected. The structure of powder steel quenched from this temperature is martensite and retained austenite (Fig. 3(a) and (b)). Fig. 3
The structure of quenched powder steel 50Ni2Mo affected by tempering temperature. Ttem: without tempering (a, b); 150°С (c, d); 450°С (e, f); 570°С (g, h); and 650°С (i, j). Magnification (from left to right): 500×, 1500×

Figure 4 shows crystal lattice microdistortions as dependent on the tempering temperature of quenched powder steel 50Ni2Mo, and Fig. 5 demonstrates the strength properties as a function of this temperature. The low values of ultimate strength and yield stress for the quenched steel without tempering are explained by a combination of porosity and low material plasticity in this state (σu ≈ σ0.2 ≈740 MPa), which results in brittle fracture under relatively low tensile stressing. Tempering at 150°С has a scarce effect on the level of crystal lattice microdistortions (Fig. 4) and hardness also remains practically unchanged (Fig. 5), ultimate strength and yield stress becoming almost twice as high. This behaviour of the strength properties may be due to the effect of blue-brittleness [10]. The values of Hc, and ρ decrease by 13 and 5 per cent, respectively, and μmax grows by 11 per cent (Fig. 6). Maximum magnetization remains constant, and this points to the constancy of the phase composition of the steel at Тtem ≤ 150°С. Fig. 4
The effect of tempering temperature on crystal lattice microdistortions for oil-quenched powder steel 50Ni2Mo (Tquen = 820°С) Fig. 5
Ultimate strength, conventional yield strength,specific elongation, and Vickers microhardnessaffected by tempering temperature foroil-quenched powder steel 50Ni2Mo (Tquen = 820°С) Fig. 6
The magnetic characteristics and electric conductivity of oil-quenched powder steel 50Ni2Mo affected by tempering temperature (Tquen = 820°С)

When Ttem = 200°С, the magnitude of lattice microdistortions slightly decreases owing to higher intensity of carbon precipitation from the hard solution (Fig. 4). X-ray phase studies revealed approximately 4 per cent of austenite, and this points to the onset ofaustenite decomposition. The hardness starts to decrease and becomes 6.50 GPa. The ultimate strength remains practically unchanged and the yield stress grows to 1240 MPa. The rate of change in the magnetic characteristics and electrical resistivity of the specimens grows. A sharp increase in Mmax corroborates the decomposition of retained austenite, which ceases at about 300°С. Note that the coercive force practically ceases to decrease at this temperature. At the same time, maximum magnetic permeability keeps growing and electricаl resistivity continues to decrease.

At higher tempering temperatures, steel softening takes place due to the annihilation of dislocations, the growth of subgrain size and carbon precipitation causing lower martensite lattice tetragonality. In the range of tempering temperatures between 250°С and 650°С, the hardness decreases from 5.70 to 2.60 GPa (Fig. 5). The dependence σ0.2(Ttem) is similar to σu(Ttem). In the range of tempering temperatures 250–650°С, the ultimate strength and yield stress decrease practically in a linear manner from 1500 to 680 MPa and from 1200 to 450 MPa, respectively. Specific elongation monotonically increases with Ttem over the whole range of tempering temperatures studied. The value of δ is 0.8 per cent for quenched specimens and 4.7 per cent for specimens tempered at 650°С.

The behaviour of magnetic characteristics as functions of Ttem for specimens tempered at temperatures ranging between 450°С and 650°С is non-monotonic. Some increase (about 6 per cent) in the coercive force on this portion is attributable to the effect of a few factors. On the one hand, as the tempering temperature rises, internal stresses, and the density of crystal structure defects decrease, and this causes lower Hc. Second, it is known [11] that, when martensite is tempered, lamellar carbide particles coherently coupled with the α-phase are formed. According to the data found in reference [12], carbide spheroidization occurring at high temperatures facilitates magnetization reversal.

On the other hand, as the tempering temperature rises (the rate of carbon diffusion in the α-phase proves to be relatively high), carbide particles grow larger. In carbon steels, this starts at 400°С, and, with the presence of molybdenum, at 550°С [13]. The presence of nickel in steel favours the growth of carbide particles. Figure 3(e) and (f) demonstrates the beginning of highly dispersed carbide precipitation, and Fig. 3(g), (h), (i), and (j) shows larger carbide inclusions. When highly dispersed carbides are precipitated and then enlarged, Hc grows due to higher critical fields required for domain wall motion through low-magnetic inclusions in magnetization reversal [14]. According to reference [15], the greatest interaction of domain walls with inclusions is observed when the size of the inclusions is close to domain wall thickness. It is the effect of all these factors that causes a peak on the dependence Hc(Ttem) at Ttem ≈ 570°С.

The contribution of the hysteresis ensuing from the interaction of domain walls with carbide inclusions into Hc, all other things being equal, is much governed by carbon content in steel: according to reference [2], the peak on the dependence Hc(Ttem) for a powder steel similar in the composition but different only in lower carbon content is several times as low as in steel 50Ni2Mo.
The dependences μmax(Ttem) and Br(Ttem) are similar to each other, and their behaviour is contrary to that of Hc(Ttem) (Fig. 6).

According to [16], the 4 per cent decrease in maximum magnetization in the range Ttem = 400–650°С is explainable by three possible reasons. First, it is the formation of low-magnetic cementite and carbon precipitation from the α-hard solution; second, it is the transition of ferromagnetic low-temperature carbide ε-FexC into paramagnetic cementite, close to cementite in its structure, composition, and properties; finally, it is the transition of iron atoms from the ‘ferromagnetic state’ (α-hard solution) into the paramagnetic one (paramagnetic cementite), the content of carbon in ε-carbide being higher than in cementite.

The value of electrical resistivity (Fig. 6(b)) monotonically decreases with rising Ttem. This is mainly due to the lower tetragonality of the martensite lattice and higher perfection of the crystal lattice, which agrees with the results of the X-ray diffraction analysis (Fig. 4).

Figure 7 presents tempering temperature dependences of the coercive force values obtained from minor magnetic hysteresis loops at maximum induction bmax = 0.4 T and bmax = 0.05 T for powder steel 50Ni2Mo. The behaviours of the dependences Hc(Ttem) and hc 0.4(Ttem) are identical, namely, as Ttem rises, the coercive force decreases (Figs 6(a) and 7(b)). In low fields, the coercivity trend with growing tempering temperature is qualitatively different, namely, hc 0.05 grows more than by a factor of 1.5 as Ttem rises from 200°С to 570°С. The fact is that, in the process of magnetization to saturation and subsequent magnetization reversal, all ‘magnetic heterogeneities’ (crystal structure defects, low-magnetic inclusions, and internal stress gradients) containing all possible critical fields participate in the formation of Hc. When the specimens are magnetized with minor hysteresis loops, including the Rayleigh region, the domain walls that are pinned on defects with critical fields higher than the applied one do not participate in the formation of the coercive force. The growth of hc 0.05 with tempering temperature may bear witness to a higher concentration of defects with critical fields of lower values. Fig. 7
The effect of tempering temperature on thecoercive force obtained from minor hysteresis loops at bmax = 0.4 T (a) and bmax = 0.05 T (b) for oil-quenched powder steel 50Ni2Mo (Tquen = 820°С)

Investigation into the effect of elastic–plastic strains on the magnetic characteristics of specimens in different structural states is of interest when one develops methods to estimate acting stresses in sintered powder steels. In Fig. 8(a), relative values of the coercive force Нс/Нс0 for specimens tempered at different temperatures are shown as dependent on applied tensile stresses reduced to yield stress, Нс0being the coercive force of the specimens in the initial state before tension. Figure 8(b) and (c) shows the same dependences for maximum magnetic permeability and residual induction. Fig. 8
Relative coercive force (a), maximum magnetic permeability (b), and residual magnetic induction (c) as dependent on external tensile stresses reduced to yield stress for specimens made of powder steel 50Ni2Mo after quenching followed by tempering

The external tensile stress dependences of relative coercive force seen to be non-monotonic for the most part: the coercive force decreases at the initial stage of tension and increases with a further growth of tensile stresses, thus forming a minimum on the dependenceНс/Нс0(σ/σ0.2). The reasons for this minimum in the region of elastic tensile deformations of conventional cast carbon steels were extensively discussed in the literature [3, 17, 18]. Summarizing the data available in the literature, one can state that the non-monotonic behaviour of Нс in tension is mainly governed by the effect of two factors. First, it is the contribution from induced magnetic anisotropy arising in elastic deformation, which is associated with the rearrangement of the domain structure. For materials whose magnetostriction and external stresses in tension have the same signs, tensile elastic stresses facilitate the processes of magnetization reversal along the axis of applied loading. As this takes place, 90° of the domain walls actually disappear, and this leads to some decrease in the coercive force of the specimens. With the further tension in the elastic strain region and then in the plastic one, the growth of Нс caused by growing internal stresses and dislocation density in the material becomes predominant. The competition between these two opposite trends on the Нс(σ) dependence results in a minimum.

Similar dependences were observed in reference [19] on powder structural steel containing the same quantity of alloying elements, though with lower carbon concentration (0.35 mass%). It was found that, the higher the specimen porosity, the deeper isthe minimum on the dependence Нс/Нс0(ε) (similar to Нс/Нс0(σ/σ0.2)), all other things being equal. It was explained by the formation of closure domain structures containing mainly 90° domain walls near pores, and it was supposed that in porous steels there are much more 90° domain wall, than in cast steels with the same structural state. Since magnetoelastic anisotropy causes a reduction in the volume of 90° domain walls, in the elastic deformation of powder steels with higher porosity, and, hence, higher concentration of 90° domain walls this reduction is more pronounced.

In the instance discussed in this article, the effect of different porosities on the depth of the minimum on the dependences Нс/Нс0(σ/σ0.2) is minimized, as all the specimens have the same porosity (about 5 per cent). However, the role of pores in magnetic terms can be played by low-magnetic inclusions of cementite if the size of the low-magnetic inclusions is such that closure domains with 90° domain walls can emerge near them. It is reasonable to suppose that the magnitude and position of the minimum on the dependences Нс/Нс0(σ/σ0.2) are governed by structural state differences, namely, the number and size of carbide inclusions.

Lower magnetic rigidity of the powder steel in the initial stage of tension causes higher maximum magnetic permeability. Further tension accompanied by increasing magnetic rigidity leads to a decrease in μmax (Fig. 8(b)). The behaviour of residual magnetic induction depending on applied stresses for specimens tempered at temperatures below 250°С is similar to the behaviour of maximum magnetic permeability, whereas Br monotonically decreases as σ grows for specimens tempered at 490°С and above (Fig. 8(c)).

It is obvious from Fig. 8(a) that, for powder steel 50Ni2Mo, the coercive force obtained in the maximum applied field first decreases under deformation and then increases with a further growth of external tensile stresses, thus forming a minimum on the dependences Нс/Нс0(σ/σ0.2). Under magnetization reversal in low fields (in the Rayleigh region) the situation is opposite: at the initial stage of deformation the coercive force first increases and then decreases, thus forming a peak on the curves hc 0.05/hc0 0.05(σ/σ0.2) (Fig. 9(а)). The position of this peak varies within the range (0.3–1.0)σ0.2 depending on the tempering temperature. Under magnetization reversal in medium fields (bmax = 0.4 T), the coercive force of all the specimens grows monotonically with external tensile stresses (Fig. 9(b)). In the elastic region of tension, hc 0.4 grows by 10 per cent for specimens tempered at 150°С, 570°С, and 650°С and by more than 20 per cent for specimens tempered at 250°С and 490°С. The dependences hc 0.4/hc0 0.4(σ/σ0.2) for quenched specimens without tempering coincide with those for specimens tempered at 150°С. Fig. 9
The coercive force obtained from minor hysteresis loops at bmax = 0.05 T (a) and bmax = 0.4 T (b) as dependent on external tensile stresses reduced to yield stress for specimens made of powder steel 50Ni2Mo after quenching followed by tempering

The coercive force measured in low fields (bmax = 0.05 T) can grow by several tens to hundred percent depending on applied stresses in the elastic region, whereas the variation of Hc, hc 0.4, μmax and Br does not exceed 30 per cent. Note, however, that the value of hc 0.05 is determined with a greater error than Hc, hc 0.4, μmax and Br. Therefore, the quantity hc 0.4 is more preferable for estimating the level of tensile stresses in products made of heat-treated powder steel 50Ni2Mo, since, first, it is determined with a smaller error and, second, it monotonically grows up to specimen failure.

sec.title: 4 CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: It has been demonstrated that the quenching temperature dependences of coercivity, maximum magnetic permeability, and magnetization in a maximum applied field enable the underheating of powder steel 50Ni2Mo for quenching to be checked. It has been found that the steel studied is less sensitive to exceed the temperature of quenching up to 910°С.

The monotonic behaviour of coercivity, maximum magnetic permeability, and residual magnetic induction as the tempering temperature rises to 400°С allows their use as parameters for magnetic testing of the quality of tempering of powder steel 50Ni2Mo quenched from 820°С.

In the practically important elastic region of uni-axial tension, as tensile stresses grow, there is a decrease in the coercive force obtained from hysteresis loops in a maximum applied field, an increase in maximum magnetic permeability and the coercive force obtained from minor hysteresis loops, residual magnetic induction varying only slightly. The coercive force values obtained from hysteresis loops in medium (hc 0.4) and low (hc 0.05) fields are the most preferable for estimating the level of tensile stresses in the elastic region in products and structural members made of heat-hardened powder steel 50Ni2Mo. However, it is hc 0.4 alone that monotonically varies over the whole elastic region; besides, hc 0.05 is determined with a much greater error.

sec.title: FUNDING
sec.p: The study was supported by RFBR [grant number 09-08-01091] and UB RAS interdisciplinary project 09 -M-13-2001.

sec.title: CONFLICT OF INTEREST
sec.p: The authors declare that there is no conflict of interest.
